Lasse Koskela wrote:
> *This message was transferred with a trial version of CommuniGate(tm) Pro*
> Hi Robert,
> 
> On 6/20/07, robert_kuropkat <robert@...> wrote:
>>  I am deciding whether to push JUnit 4 or 3.8 with our group.  The last
>>  notes I can find on the JUnit site bemoan the fact JUnit4 has not been
>>  integrated into any IDEs or test and build tools yet.  However that
>>  was over a year ago.  Any update on this?  I would be particularly
>>  interested in:
>>
>>  Eclipse
>>  Netbeans
>>  IntelliJ
>>  Cruise Control
>>  Fitnesse
>>  JSystem
>>  maven
>>  cactus
> 
> I've used Eclipse, IntelliJ IDEA, CruiseControl and Maven on projects
> that used JUnit 4. As far as I can remember, there was no need to
> tweak anything about the IDEs or CruiseControl but we needed to
> install a snapshot version of Maven's surefire plugin because JUnit 4
> support wasn't yet released back then but it's now supported out of
> the box so that shouldn't be an issue anymore.
> 
> I'm not sure how Fitnesse relates to JUnit(?), I haven't used Cactus
> in ages, and I hadn't even heard of JSystem before now so no comment
> about those.
> 
> I hope this helps,
> Lasse
> 

Lasse,

Thanks for the quick response.  Your response makes me feel a lot 
better.  I was just reading up on Eclipse and JUnit4 so I am glad to 
hear most of the rest is good also.

As for the other products, JSystem I saw listed on the JUnit pages as a 
tool to expand unit testing to system/functional testing.  Fitnesse (if 
it is even still maintained) was intended to pick up testing where the 
developer leaves off and the customer picks up so is geared towards 
customer definable acceptance tests.  I need to go read up again because 
I don't recall if it uses JUnit under the covers, or can be used to at 
least re-run the JUnit tests on the customer facing test site or what. 
I was just covering all bases on my request.

Thanks again,
Robert Kuropkat
